title: Staphylococci properties, diseases, diagnosis, and management approach
shortDescription: In this lecture, Dr. Mobeen discusses the definition, description, morphology, species, diagnostic tests, diseases, and the management approach to staphylococci.
longDescription:
In this lecture, Dr. Mobeen discusses the following topics about Staphylococci:

  • Definition
  • Description
  • Morphology
    • Shape
    • Color
    • Cell wall
    • Cell membrane
    • Penicillin-binding protein
  • Species
    • S. Aureus
    • S. Epidermidis
    • S. Saprophyticus
  • Diagnostic Tests
    • Gram staining
    • Catalase test
    • Coagulase test
    • Novobiocin test
    • NaCl test
    • Mannitol fermentation
  • Diseases
    • Skin infections
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Bacteremia
    • Wound, catheters, and splinter infections
    • Prosthesis infections
    • Splenic abscesses
  • The Management Approach to Staphylococci
    • IV vs Oral medications
    • MRSA vs. Penicillin sensitive pathogen management
notes:
This genera of bacteria is based on the following common characteristics, these are spherical, gram positive pathogens that lack endospores and are catalase positive. Remember catalase positive. Streptococci are also gram positive but are catalase negative.

Medically Important Species

Presence or absence of coagulase enzyme subdivides staphylococcus genus into more virulent Staphylococcus Aureus which is coagulase positive, and Staphylococcus Epidermidis and Staphylococcus Saprophyticus that are coagulase negative.

S. Saprophyticus is novobiocin resistant, and S. Epidermidis is novobiocin sensitive.

Remember these three are medically important pathogens, otherwise there are 49 species and 27 subspecies in this genera.

Staphylococci Identification

Let’s look at the chart that places these pathogens on the gram positive scale. As mentioned above, these are gram positive cocci, catalase positive, and S. Aureus is Coagulase positive, while S. Sap is novobiocin resistant and S. Epi is novobiocin sensitive.

 

Normal Flora

While at the topic of genera and species, let’s find out where these pathogens live on our bodies. S. Aureus is the normal flora of nares and to a lesser extent the throat. S. Epidermidis is the normal flora of the skin and S. Saprophyticus is usually found in the perineal area of men and women and genital tract of women. It is a frequent cause of UTI in young sexually active women. (Honeymoon cystitis is usually caused by S. Saprophyticus.) 

 

 

 

Infections

These are usually opportunistic and cause infections of skin, bones, heart, urinary tract, spleen, prosthesis, wounds, etc. Remember the most virulent and infectious species is S. Aureus.

Methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus also called MRSA (mursa) is notorious for causing infections in hospitalized patients.

 

Important Points

Interestingly Staphylococci can cause infections in both the aerobic and anaerobic conditions, at high temperature ranges, and these bad bugs grow in high salt conditions too.

 

Morphology

These pathogens are spherical, non-motile, and make irregular grape like colonies. Their size ranges between 0.5 to 1.5 micrometer. Many species are capsular. These pathogens also form a biofilm or a slime layer around them. This biofilm helps them stick to catheters and tissues while also helping them escape phagocytosis.

Important Proteins

Some important proteins these bugs possess to tunnel through the tissue are hyaluronidase - which helps them breaks down proteoglycans, staphylokinase - to break down fibrin clots, proteases - to break down proteins, and lipases - to break down lipids and fats. Lipases help staphylococci infect sebaceous glands.

 

Cytoplasmic Membrane

The inner cytoplasmic membrane contains the penicillin binding proteins (PBP). Methicillin resistant bugs alter their penicillin binding proteins. This altered structure of the penicillin binding protein helps staphylococci resist penicillin. Note that these penicillin resistant pathogens become resistant to all beta lactam class of antibiotics. That is they resist penicillins, synthetic penicillins, cephalosporins, and carbapenems. 

Note that Staphylococci have to acquire mecA gene which helps them make the altered PBP.

Cell Wall

Bacterial cell wall contains peptidoglycans. This layer is synthesized by penicillin-binding-proteins that we just discussed above. Beta lactam drugs disrupt the normal function of the penicillin-binding-proteins, which results in incorrect peptidoglycan synthesis. This in turn causes breaks in the cell walls and the pathogen dies. Peptidoglycan layer also acts like an endotoxin. Teichoic acid and lipoteichoic acids are attached to the peptidoglycan layer or the plasma membrane. These are poorly immunogenic and can trigger antibody response.

 


Surface adhesion proteins


A large number of such proteins are present. These proteins help bind staphylococci to foreign material like catheters, splinters, etc., and elastin, collagen, and fibrinogen of the host tissues.
Coagulase protein that is used to identify staphylococcus aureus is actually one of these surface adhesion proteins. It is also called a clumping factor because it helps pathogen clump together. Coagulase binds to fibrinogen and converts it to insoluble fibrin. Another surface protein called protein A binds with the Fc portion of immunoglobulin-G (IgG) and makes it unavailable to bind with phagocytes. This helps prevent opsonization of the pathogen and resulting phagocytosis. 

Remember antibody and complement coating on a pathogen marks it for the phagocytes to eat it up. This marking is called opsonization.
 

 

 


Enzymes

Exfoliatin is an exotoxin that causes scalded skin syndrome.

Enterotoxin B causes food poisoning with vomiting and diarrhea.

Toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) is a superantigen. It binds to MHC class II molecules on the antigen presenting cells (APCs). We will discuss this more separately, over here just a brief discussion. This binding of the TSST-1 to MHC-II causes massive release of interleukin-1 (IL-1), interleukin 2 (IL-2), and tumor necrosis factor (TNF) from the immune cells. These cytokines in turn cause toxic shock. Tampons left in place for long time can cause this toxic shock when S. Aureus grows in the area of tampons, penetrates the vaginal walls, and triggers the immune response discussed above.

Beta lactamases, these proteins are secreted by the pathogen to catch the penicillins outside the pathogen and prevent these penicillin molecules from entering the bug and killing it. Very smart of this bad boy or girl. What is the gender of staphylococci? Hmm? Let’s know if you know...

 

Important Considerations

Usually early prosthetic infections are caused by S. Aureus. Early means three months or lesser. Late prosthesis infections are caused by S. Epi. And, late means greater than three months. 

Keep in mind, S. Aureus and S. Epi are the most common healthcare related causes of infective endocarditis (IE). S. Epi usually causes right sided heart infection in IV drug abusers. S. Aureus usually causes infection after vascular manipulation, especially cardiac catheters etc. A clinical gem is that there may be pain at the point of entry of the catheter when the infection has occurred. It is not always the case though.
Splenic abscesses are mostly caused by Staphylococci, Streptococci, and Salmonella. So this bad bug is involved here as well.

 


Important Diagnostic Tests for Staphylococci

As discussed earlier these are gram positive. These are also catalase positive. Catalase enzyme converts H2O2 to H2O and Oxygen. Rubbing a wire loop on the colony and then dipping it in H2O2 will show bubbles when oxygen is produced.
Staphylococci are beta hemolytic on blood agar culture. Staphylococci make golden colonies on sheep blood agar. Aureus means gold. This is why S. Aureus is called Aureus. 
Staphylococcus aureus is also coagulase positive. Remember from our earlier discussion that coagulase is a surface adhesion protein present on S. Aureus. It converts fibrinogen to fibrin. Fibrin in turn helps build walls around the pathogens. Which makes it difficult to phagocytose. To test for the presence of coagulase put the pathogen in plasma. If plasma coagulates then the pathogens are coagulase positive. Remember coagulase positive pathogens are more virulent. Coagulase negative pathogens are usually less virulent. 
We know that S. Epi and S. Saprophyticus are both coagulase negative. How do we differentiate between them? Well, we do the novobiocin test. S. Epi is novobiocin sensitive. While, S. Sap is not. 

Mannitol is fermented by S. Aureus and is not by others.
7.5% NaCl inhibits growth of most other pathogens but not Staphylococcus aureus.

 


High Level Management

Penicllin Sensitive

If the pathogens are not penicillin resistant. Which unfortunately is a small number now a days -only 10%, then we can administer penicillin, or semisynthetic penicillins like methicillin, nafcillin, oxacillin, or dicloxacillin. Cephalosporins and carbapenem will work too.

Methicillin Resistant

For the methicillin resistant species which are the majority of the pathogens now a days, use the following approach.

For oral medication the possible choices are sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim (SMX/TMP), or tetracyclines like doxycycline, clindamycin, minocycline, linezolid. 
For the IV route Vancomycin is the best choice. Alternatives to vancomycin for the IV route are daptomycin, tigecycline, and linezolid. Note vancomycin will cover both the penicillin sensitive and resistant pathogens. You can’t go wrong with it.

Finally a note of caution, now a days vancomycin resistance is seen as well. It is rare but is observed. This evolving resistance will make the management of Staphylococci difficult in the coming days.

title: Staphylococcus - Superantigens
shortDescription:
How do staphylococci cause toxic shock syndrome? 
Superantigens are the answer. 
In this important video session, Dr. Syed discusses superantigens in the context of staphylococci.

Following topics are discussed:

What are superantigens?
What important pathogens release superantigens?
What superantigens are released?
Normal controlled immune response to an antigen.
How does a superantigen cause massive abnormal activation of the immune system?
Symptoms of the toxic shock syndrome as a result of superantigen activity.
Labs
longDescription:
How do staphylococci cause toxic shock syndrome? 
Superantigens are the answer. 
In this important video session, Dr. Syed discusses superantigens in the context of staphylococci.

Following topics are discussed:

  • What are superantigens?
  • What important pathogens release superantigens?
  • What superantigens are released?
  • Normal controlled immune response to an antigen.
  • How does a superantigen cause massive abnormal activation of the immune system?
  • Symptoms of the toxic shock syndrome as a result of superantigen activity.
  • Labs
notes:
Superantigen

A superantigen in contrast to non-superantigens activates a large number of helper T cells. Important pathogens that produce superantigens are staphylococcus Aureus, streptococcus pyogenes and some viruses. The superantigen by Staphylococcus Aureus is it’s exotoxin named TSST-1 and the superantigen from Streptococcus Pyogenes is Exotoxin-A.

 

Normal T Cell Activation

Let’s look at how an antigen activates the immune system, and then we will explain how a superantigen works. Usually an antigen is taken up by an antigen presenting cell (APC.) Inside the APC, the antigen is processed in many steps that are not necessary to mention here. As a result of this processing, small antigen pieces that are usually lipids are formed and packed in the vesicles called endosomes. APCs also have MHC II molecules formed in their rough endoplasmic reticulum. These molecules are made of alpha and beta chains. These chains have a peptide binding site where the antigen pieces are loaded. The peptide binding site is usually kept closed by the CLIP part of an invariant chain protein. This protein here is (labeled li). These complexes are packed in vesicles called exocytic vesicles.

Going back to the antigen processing, after an endosome is formed with the antigen pieces in it, it is fused with the exocytic vesicles that contain the MHC II complexes. Inside this fused vesicle the CLIP part of the li protein is cleaved to expose the antigen binding site on the MHC II complex. Once this site is available antigens from the endosomes are loaded in it. This antigen loaded MHC II complex is exposed on the cell surface to be recognized by the T cell receptors on the helper T cells. As a result, T cell receptors bind with this antigen loaded MHC II molecule. CD4 is also needed for a complete binding. As a result of this binding and costimulatory signals the T cell and the macrophage become active and the immune response starts. This is the normal mechanism. Let’s now check how a superantigen causes this mechanism to become life threatening for us.

 

Superantigen and Massive T Cell Activation Resulting in Cytokine Storm

A superantigen binds to the MHC II complex without the need to be processed inside an APC. A superantigen can attach with any already available MHC II molecule on the APC surface. This superantigen also binds to T cell receptor without being specific to this receptor. This means a superantigen will bind with many helper T cells and activate them all. This activation of the T helper cells causes release of IFN-gamma. Which in turn causes macrophages to become active as well. Activated macrophages in turn release IL1, IL6, and TNF-alpha. This massive activation of many T helper cells and macrophages causes a cytokine storm.

Interestingly a large number of us have antibodies to these superantigens, however, people that develop toxic shock syndrome seem to lack sufficient quantities of antibodies to these superantigens. As a result they are vulnerable to toxic shock syndrome.

Note, that superantigens do not care for a specific T cell, hence, these antigens activate a large number of T helper cells. This is why these antigens are called superantigens.

 

Symptoms

We will discuss the CDC’s guidelines and the causes of symptoms with management in detail in the lecture on toxic shock syndrome. It is sufficient to know in this lecture that there is severe hypotension, fever, vomiting, diarrhea, myalgias, skin desquamation, and multiple organ failure. Death can occur within days.

 

Labs

Let’s also take a quick look at the labs. Because of the tissue damage one might see the following:

  • Increased AST, ALT, and Bilirubin.
  • Increased levels of creatine phosphokinase CPK

title: Why do superantigens cause cytokine storm?
shortDescription:
Superantigens are capable of massive immune cell activation. This, in turn, results in a large quantity of cytokines like IFN-gamma, IL1, IL6, TNF, etc. to be released.

This short video answers the question, why do superantigens cause toxic shock syndrome?
notes: Superantigens are capable of massive immune cell activation. This, in turn, results in a large quantity of cytokines like IFN-gamma, IL1, IL6, TNF, etc. to be released. This short video answers the question, why do superantigens cause toxic shock syndrome?

title: Staphylococcus - Toxic Shock Syndrome and Its Management
shortDescription: Toxic shock syndrome is a rare but deadly disease most common in young women using super-absorbent tampons. Staphylococcal toxin TSST-1 is responsible for this syndrome. Majority of the patient that fall ill with toxic shock syndrome also lack an adequate humoral response to the toxic shock syndrome toxin. In this brief video Dr. Mobeen discusses the syndrome, its presentation, diagnosis, pathophysiology, and the management.
longDescription: Toxic shock syndrome is a rare but deadly disease most common in young women using super-absorbent tampons. Staphylococcal toxin TSST-1 is responsible for this syndrome. Majority of the patient that fall ill with toxic shock syndrome also lack an adequate humoral response to the toxic shock syndrome toxin. In this brief video Dr. Mobeen discusses the syndrome, its presentation, diagnosis, pathophysiology, and the management.
notes:
Introduction

This rare but life-threatening disease is characterized by fever, desquamating rash, hypotension, circulatory collapse, and multiple organ failure. As mentioned in the supterantigen topics most of the cases of toxic shock syndrome (TSS) are due to the toxic shock syndrom toxin 1 (TSST-1) from staphylococcus  aureus. Although, streptococci exotoxin-A and some viruses can also cause this disease. Important to note that in most cases the patient does not have adequate antibody response to the TSST-1 toxin.

TSS used to occur more commonly with the use of superabsorbent tampons in menstruating women, however, with the manufacturers removing or labeling such products the incidence of toxic shock has reduced.

Can TSS Occur in Menopausal Women, Men, and Children?

Remember that toxic shock can also occur in men, postmenopausal women, and children. Usually the causes in such cases are surgeries, wounds with packings and skin wounds.

Symptoms

Symptoms can include:

  • Fever
  • Sunburn like rash
  • Diarrhea
  • Vomiting
  • Redness of eyes, mouth, and nose
  • Muscle aches and pains
  • Hypotension
  • Confusion
  • Seizures
  • Headache

Remember that these symptoms can start at the 5th day of menstruation.

CDC Criteria

(Keep in mind, if you suspect toxic shock syndrome while the CDC criteria is unmet, you should start managing the patient for toxic shock syndrome.)

General

  • Fever > 102 degrees fahrenheit
  • Hypotension: Systolic BP < 90 mmHg in adults
  • Rash: diffuse macular erythroderma
  • Desquamation, especially of the palms and soles after 1 to 2 weeks of of onset of illness.

Organ System Involvement

  • Muscular: myalgia, CPK > 2x the normal
  • Renal: BUN or serum creatinine > 2x the upper limit of the normal. No UTI but Pyuria (> 5 white blood cell count in high power field.)
  • Hepatic: bilirubin or transaminase > 2x the upper limit of the normal.
  • Hematologic: Platelets < 100,000 per microliter
  • CNS: alteration in consciousness without focal neurological deficit in the absence of fever and hypotension.

Negative Findings

  • Usually blood and CSF cultures are negative for S. Aureus (blood may be positive in some cases.)
  • Negative tests for Rocky mountain spotted fever.
  • Negative tests for leptospirosis.
  • Negative tests for measles.

Disease Progression and Recovery

Once the toxin starts acting, it can rapidly involve multiple organs including heart, kidney, and liver. 10-20% of the patients die of this rapid progress and organ failure.

Recovery usually accompanies desquamation of the skin of palms and soles by the 7th day of the syndrome.

Diagnosis

Diagnosis is clinical. Usually a menstruating young woman presenting with above symptoms should arise the suspicion of toxic shock. Presence of a tampon on vaginal examination, and presence of gram positive staphylococci, with culture and toxin production are confirmatory.

Management

Management must be immediate and aggressive. Following are the management steps.

 

 

Empiric Therapy

  • Mainstay of the therapy is supportive.
  • Remove any material from vaginal canal, wounds, nasal packings, etc.
  • Clean/drain/debride the wounds.
  • IV fluid resuscitation (10-20L/day)
  • Vasopressors like dopamine and norepinephrine may be needed.
  • Empiric treatment with IV antistaphylococcal antibiotic e.g. flucloxacillin or vancomycin is needed.

Antistaphylococcal Therapy

Vancomycin

  • Adults: 15-20 mg/kg dose every 8 to 12 hours. A single dose should not exceed 2 g/dose.
  • Children: 40 mg/kg IV daily in four divided doses.

Protein Synthesis Inhibitors

Add protein synthesis inhibitor to reduce/inhibit toxin production. Clindamycin. Linezolid can be used in case of resistance to clindamycin.

Clindamycin

  • Adults: 900 mg IV every 8 hours.
  • Children: 25-40 mg/kg daily in three divided doses.

Linezolid

  • Adults: 600 mg oral or IV every 12 hours
  • Children: 10 mg/kg IV oral or IV every 12 hours

After culture and susceptibility following medications can be used.

For methicillin susceptible pathogen 

Use Clindamycin as above and add oxacillin or nafcillin as following:

  • Adults: 2 g IV every four hours.
  • Children: 100 to 150 mg/kg IV in four divided doses for a day.

For Methicillin Resistant S. Aurues (MRSA) 

Use clindamycin plus vancomycin or linezolid alone or in combination with vancomycin based on the site of infection.

Eliminate The Carrier State 

Obtain nares culture. If S. Aureus is present then use mupirocin for five days to eradicate the pathogen. Half of mupirocin from the tube is applied in one nostril and the other half in to the other nostril.

Administer IV Immunoglobulins

In cases of streptococcal toxin IV immunoglobulins against the toxins are used in severe cases.

Advice at the Time of Discharge

  • Women who recover should be advised to not use tampons for a year.
  • Also inform the patient that their immune system’s response is not adequate to these toxins, hence there is a risk of recurrence.

Cause of Death

  • Refractory cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Cardiac myopathy 
  • Irreversible respiratory failure 
  • Bleeding due to coagulation defects.

title: Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome
shortDescription: Dr. Mobeen discusses the pathophysiology, presentation, and management of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.
longDescription: Dr. Mobeen discusses the pathophysiology, presentation, and management of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.
notes:
Staphylococci release exotoxins that cause three kinds of syndromes/diseases.

  • Gastroenteritis
  • Toxic Shock Syndrome
  • Scalded Skin Syndrome (Bullous Impetigo - local form)

In this lecture Dr. Mobeen discusses the pathophysiology, presentation, and management of the scalded skin syndrome.

Notes

Staphylococcal exotoxins cause three different diseases.

  • Gastroenteritis 
  • Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS)
  • Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS)
    • Keep in mind that bullous exfoliation is the localized form of scalded skin syndrome.

Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) usually occurs in neonates or children. Usually the focus is the severed umbilical cord, or an infected area of skin.

Pathology

Staphylococcus aureus grows in the focus of infection and releases exotoxins named exfoliatin A and/or exfoliatin B. These toxins diffuse in the systemic circulation and cause scalded skin syndrome.

  • Exfoliatin A is encoded by ETA gene of a phage, while Exfoliatin B is mediated by a plasmid.
  • Exfoliatin A is heat stable, i.e. it usually escapes boiling for 20 minutes. While Exfoliatin B is heat labile.

Remember staphylococci do not have to cause invasive infection to have these toxins diffuse into the circulation and cause systemic upset.

These toxins are superantigens. They cause cleavage of the epidermis at the level of stratum spinosum (below the stratum granulosum and above the stratum spinosum) by dissolving the mucopolysaccharide matrix and breaking desmoglein-1 in the desmosomes that bind the skin cells especially the cells in the epidermal layers.

Why does the patient has exfoliation of the skin instead of blisters?

In reality the cleavage of the epidermis does produce blisters. But the roof of this blister is very thin and fragile and it usually collapses. This is why you don’t see blisters and instead peeling skin is observed. This also is the reason why the child recovers without any scarring. The skin peeling usually starts in one to two days at the groin, axilla and mouth and then spreads to the whole body.

Presentation

Child usually presents with

  • Red tender and moist skin
  • Fevr
  • Irritability

You may be able to find the focus of infection.

Management

Take swabs from the focus of the infection if possible for culture and sensitivity. Also take a skin snip for the histology.

Immediately start supportive therapy and antibiotics. Let’s discuss what these therapies usually are. Administer oral antibiotics in case of local disease or parenteral in case of systemic disease.

Antibiotics

Administration of semisynthetic penicillinase resistant penicillins like methicillin, nafcillin, dicloxacillin, flucloxacillin is indicated, however, if the pathogen is methicillin resistant then vancomycin is given.

Quick note on penicillinase resistant and methicillin resistant antibiotics. Most staphylococci secrete penicillinase enzyme that breaks penicillins, however, flucloxacillin, methicillin and nafcillin like antibiotics are not broken down by this enzyme. Unfortunately, there are species of S. Aureus that have acquired a mecA gene to encode for an altered penicillin binding protein and render penicillinase resistant antibiotics mentioned above inactive because these antibiotics cannot bind and inactivate the penicillin binding proteins. These pathogens are labeled as MRSA. Vancomycin is needed for MRSA. Vancomycin binds to amino acids in the cell wall and prevent further addition thus preventing the cell wall formation.

Flucloxacillin systemically. It is a penicillinase resistant penicillin.

Vancomycin can be used for MRSA (MRSA has modified penicillin binding protein.)

Clindamycin maybe added to stop bacterial toxin production. (It is a protein synthesis inhibitor - used just like in toxic shock syndrome.)

Supportive Therapy

  • Gently moisten the skin.
  • Emollients may help reduce the discomfort.
  • Topical antibiotics may be needed.
  • Hydroxyzine 2 mg/ml - 2.5 ml every 6h PRN (when needed) for pruritus.
  • Mupirocin in nostrils 3x a day for 7 days.
  • Erythromycin eye ointment - 1 strip to both lower eyelids 2x daily.
  • Cloxacillin (penicillinase resistant penicillin.) 2 mg/ml - 2 ml every 6 h on empty stomach.

Family Members Should be Tested for the Carrier State

Take groin, axilla and mouth swabs from the family members to figure out pathogen carriage.

Reducing the Recurrence

Ask to use antibacterial hand washing soaps to prevent further infections.

Recovery

Recovery is usually fast with no scarring.

title: Staphylococcal Gastroenteritis
shortDescription:
Course: Microbiology
Series: Staphylococcus

Staphylococcal gastroenteritis is an exotoxin mediated pathology with sudden onset of nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. 

​​Dr. Mobeen discusses the transmission, growth, toxin production, pathology, clinical presentation, and management of staphylococcal gastroenteritis.
longDescription:
Course: Microbiology
Series: Staphylococcus

Staphylococcal gastroenteritis is an exotoxin mediated pathology with sudden onset of nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. 

​​Dr. Mobeen discusses the transmission, growth, toxin production, pathology, clinical presentation, and management of staphylococcal gastroenteritis.
notes:
Course: Microbiology
Series: Staphylococcus

 

We are continuing our discussion about the diseases caused by staphylococci. This lecture is about staphylococcal gastroenteritis and its management.

Exotoxin Mediated

As discussed in the earlier lectures staphylococcus aureus produces enterotoxins that cause three type of diseases.

  • Toxic shock syndrome 
  • Scalded skin syndrome
  • Gastroenteritis.

In this lecture we will discuss staphylococcal gastroenteritis.

Pathology

Staphylococcal contamination usually occurs from the hands of the food handlers to the food. Inappropriate or bad storage will then allow these pathogens to grow on the food. Staphylococcus produces about fifteen enterotoxins that are superantigens. Enterotoxins are heat stable and resistant to the action of gut enzymes. Staphylococci produce enterotoxins when growing on carbohydrates and protein foods. Meats, dairy and carbs foods may contain preformed enterotoxins.

Incubation time is about 2 to 8 hours (sometimes even as late as 18 hours.) All persons that eat this food usually get sick.

Enterotoxin whips intestine into hyperactivity increasing intestinal peristalsis and also act on the local receptors that connect in the medullary centers.

 

Clinical Presentation

Patient abruptly develops nausea and profuse vomiting, diarrhea usually not significant, abdominal pain and sometimes fever. This episode continues from 12 to 24 hours.

Management

  • Administer antiemetics.
  • If patient can drink water then advice that, however, in majority of the cases IV fluid replacement will be needed.
  • Culture the contaminated food for staph and make public health authorities aware if food was from a vendor.

title: Staphylococcal Infective Endocarditis - (Staphylococcus)
shortDescription: Dr. Mobeen starts the discussion of the staphylococcal infections caused by organ invasion. This topic is the introduction to infective endocarditis in the context of staphylococcus.
longDescription:
Dr. Mobeen starts the discussion of the staphylococcal infections caused by organ invasion. This lecture is the introduction to infective endocarditis in the context of staphylococcus.

Topics discussed are:

  • What is infective endocarditis?
  • Terms to know when studying or managing infective endocarditis.
    • Infective endocarditis (IE)
    • Native valve endocarditis (NVE)
    • Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE)
    • Nosocomial infective endocarditis (NIE)
    • Community acquired infective endocarditis (CIE)
  • What tissues are susceptible to infective endocarditis?
  • What is the composition of an infective endocarditis vegetation?
  • What is the mechanism of tissue damage that leads to IE?
  • Which population group is at a higher risk of right sided IE?
  • Why are ventricular septal defects at a higher risk of developing IE in contrast to atrial septal defects?
notes:
Dr. Mobeen starts the discussion of the staphylococcal infections caused by organ invasion. This topic is the introduction to infective endocarditis in the context of staphylococcus.

Topics discussed are:

  • What is infective endocarditis?
  • Terms to know when studying or managing infective endocarditis.
    • Infective endocarditis (IE)
    • Native valve endocarditis (NVE)
    • Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE)
    • Nosocomial infective endocarditis (NIE)
    • Community acquired infective endocarditis (CIE)
  • What tissues are susceptible to infective endocarditis?
  • What is the composition of an infective endocarditis vegetation?
  • What is the mechanism of tissue damage that leads to IE?
  • Which population group is at a higher risk of right sided IE?
  • Why are ventricular septal defects at a higher risk of developing IE in contrast to atrial septal defects?

Notes

Staphylococcal Infective Endocarditis (IE)

We are continuing our discussion about the diseases caused by staphylococci. We have already discussed the diseases caused by staphylococcal exotoxins, let's now discuss the diseases that are caused by staphylococcal organ invasion. The first disease is staphylococcal infective endocarditis.

What is Infective Endocarditis (IE)?

Infection anywhere in the heart is called endocarditis. Valves, septal defects (more commonly ventricular septal defects,) chordae tendineae, mural endocardium i.e. the posterior wall of the left atrium, etc. are commonly involved tissues.

Terms

Before we start the discussion, a quick review of the terms related to IE.

Of course infective endocarditis is usually abbreviated as IE.

Native Valve Endocarditis (NVE)

If the infection is of the native valves, that is, the valves that we are born with, then the endocarditis is called native valve endocarditis and is written as NVE.

Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis (PVE)

Infections of the artificial valves, also called prosthetic valves, are called prosthetic valve endocarditis. Prosthetic valve endocarditis is usually abbreviated as PVE.

Nosocomical Infective Endocarditis (NIE)

Endocarditis acquired in the hospitals due to medical attention or invasive procedures are called nosocomial infective endocarditis and abbreviated as NIE. Keep in mind that the invasive procedures that can cause bacteremia can lead to infective endocarditis. Examples are:

  • Dental procedures
  • Urogenital procedures
  • Gastrointestinal procedures
  • Cardiac surgery
  • Peripheral or central intravascular catheterization
  • Surgical incisions through the mucous membranes or infected skin.

Nosocomial endocarditis is usually defined as the endocarditis occurring within 72 hours of hospitalization or within 8 weeks after an invasive procedure.

Community Acquired Infective Endocarditis (CIE)

Community acquired endocarditis is abbreviated as CIE. Some possible causes of CIE are chronic rheumatic heart disease, or congenital heart abnormalities.

What is The Composition of An Infective Endocarditis Vegetation?

Endocarditis causes vegetations in the heart that are composed of fibrin, platelets, pathogens, and inflammatory cells.

What are The Types of Infective Endocarditis?

Infective endocarditis is divided in two basic types:

Acute endocarditis

It is caused by coagulase positive staphylococcus and progresses rapidly within days to weeks. Acute endocarditis does not need pre existing damage to the heart.

Subacute Infective Endocarditis

Develops slowly usually in weeks to months. Many organisms can cause subactuve infective endocarditis. Some pathogens that can cause subacute infective endocarditis are coagulase negative staphylococcus epidermidis, streptococcus viridans, enterococcus, fungi, and gram negative pathogens. Subacute infective endocarditis can be polymicrobial as well.

What Tissues of The Heart Are Most Susceptible to Infective Endocarditis?

Generally any part of the heart tissue that is under stress can have endocardial damage. Platelets and fibrin accumulate on the damaged endothelium and form a plaque. This plaque in turn is an attractive place for the pathogens to stick to. Local damage causes inflammatory reaction to start. This components form an infected vegetation. This is the reason that a much bigger but low pressure atrial septal defect with significant hemodynamic consequences does not develop infective endocarditis, while a smaller, high pressure ventricular septal defect that is hemodynamically insignificant can develop infective endocarditis. 

Commonly infected tissues are aortic valve, mitral valve, chordae tendineae, and ventricular septal defects. In the IV drug abusers tricuspid valve is most commonly involved.

Remember, vegetations that develop can become obstructive or emboli.

title: Staphylococcus - Diagnosing Acute Infective Endocarditis (Modified Duke's Criteria)
shortDescription: Dr. Mobeen discusses the modified duke's criteria and the clinical presentation of acute infective endocarditis.
longDescription: Dr. Mobeen discusses the modified duke's criteria and the clinical presentation of acute infective endocarditis.
notes:
Dr. Mobeen discusses the modified duke's criteria and the clinical presentation of acute infective endocarditis. 

 

We are continuing our discussion about the diseases caused by staphylococcal organ invasion. In this series we are discussing acute infective endocarditis or staphylococcal endocarditis. In this talk we present the clinical presentation and the modified duke’s criteria to diagnose, suspect, or reject acute infective endocarditis.

 

Symptoms

  • 97% of the patients have fever. This is why a fever of unknown origin should include a suspicion of infective endocarditis as well.
  • 90% of the patients also exhibit malaise, fatigue, lethargy, and general tiredness.
  • 90% of the patients have new or changed murmurs.

 

Symptoms Due to Vascular and Embolic Phenomena

Strokes in 15% of the patients.

Subconjunctival hemorrhages (2-5%)

Cardiac Failure in 40% to 50% of the patients.

Splinter hemorrhages on nail beds. (10%)

Janeway's lesions are painless, erythematous lesions on palms and soles. Keep in mind that Osler’s nodes are painful. Janeway lesions are painless.

Spleen and kidney infarcts. Even hematuria due to the renal damage from emboli.

 

Post Infective Immune Complex Disease Related Symptoms

Immunologic phenomena develops due to immune complex depositions in varioius tissues.

Osler's nodes are tender (painful) raised lesions on the finger or toe pads. These lesions are due to immune complex deposition.

Roth’s spots, are rounded white spots on retina surrounded by hemorrhage. Usually caused by immune complex mediated vasculitis.

Postinfective immune complex based glomerulonephritis.

Diagnosis

Modified duke’s criteria

Duke’s criteria is divided into major and minor clinical, pathological, and microbiological factors. These factors are as follows.

Duke’s Major Criteria

Duke’s major criteria includes the following blood culture related findings:

  • Two positive blood cultures.
  • Persistent positive blood cultures taken more than 12 hours apart.
  • Three or more positive blood cultures taken more than 1 hour apart each.

Duke’s major criteria includes following endocardial involvement related findings:

  • Positive echo that is findings of vegetations on echo.
  • New valvular regurgitation

Duke's Minor Criteria

Duke’s Minor criteria includes following factors

  • Predisposing valvular or cardiac abnormality
  • Intravenous drug misuse
  • Pyrexia ≥ 38°C or 100.4°F
  • Embolic phenomenon
  • Vasculitic phenomenon
  • Blood cultures suggestive: organism grown but not achieving major criteria
  • Suggestive echocardiographic ﬁndings

Evaluating Infective Endocarditis Diagnosis Based on the Modified Duke's Criteria

Definitive Endocarditis

Definitive endocarditis is when 2 major or 1 major and 3 minor, or 5 minor factors are found.

Possible Endocarditis

Possible endocarditis is when one major and one minor or three minor factors are found.

 

In the next lecture, we will discuss the approach to the management of the acute infective endocarditis.

title: Current Approaches to Acute Infective Endocarditis (Staphylococcus Series)
shortDescription: Dr. Mobeen continues the discussion about infective endocarditis. In this short but important session he presents the management approach to acute infective endocarditis. He discusses the treatment approach when the patient is not acutely ill, when the patient is acutely ill, and when the culture and sensitivity is available and you know if the pathogen is methicillin sensitive or methicillin resistant.
longDescription: Dr. Mobeen continues the discussion about infective endocarditis. In this short but important session he presents the management approach to acute infective endocarditis. He discusses the treatment approach when the patient is not acutely ill, when the patient is acutely ill, and when the culture and sensitivity is available and you know if the pathogen is methicillin sensitive or methicillin resistant.
notes:
Dr. Mobeen continues the discussion about infective endocarditis. In this short but important session he presents the management approach to acute infective endocarditis. He discusses the treatment approach when the patient is not acutely ill, when the patient is acutely ill, and when the culture and sensitivity is available and you know if the pathogen is methicillin sensitive or methicillin resistant.

Notes

We are continuing our discussion about the diseases caused by staphylococcal organ invasion. Current topic is the management approaches to acute infective endocarditis or staphylococcal endocarditis. 

General Principles

  • Bactericidal therapy is necessary in infective endocarditis. 
  • Dose the antibiotic administration in a way to create a continuous antimicrobial concentration in patient’s serum.
  • Perform the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) test repeatedly.
  • If the patient is not acutely ill, and you suspect that patient may have acute infective endocarditis then it is preferable to wait for the blood culture and sensitivity.
  • Acutely ill patients with signs and symptoms of the acute infective endocarditis should be started on empirical therapy while you wait for the cultures. Once the culture result has arrived then adjust the therapy according to the identified pathogen and sensitivity.
  • Duration of the therapy is usually six weeks. Remember duration is counted from the day the blood culture becomes negative (provided that it was positive when the therapy started.)

Management Approach

With these considerations, let’s look at the management approach.

Let’s discuss empiric therapy first.

Empiric Therapy

Basic principles of the empiric therapy are following:

  • Therapy should cover the most common pathogens known to cause the infective endocarditis. These include Staphylococci both methicillin susceptible (MSSA) and methicillin resistant (MRSA), Streptococci, and Enterococci.
  • Empiric therapy should be started after 2 to 3 positive blood cultures from different venipunctures obtained at intervals of 30 to 60 minutes.
  • Safest route for empiric therapy is to start with Vancomycin, 15 to 20 mg/kg of body weight administered every 8 to 12 hours. Keep in mind that a single dose should not exceed 2 g.
  • Consult a cardiac surgeon early in case of suspected complications like prosthetic valves or heart failure.

Definitive Therapy for Staphylococcus Aureus

Let’s now look at staph aureus focused definitive therapy.

Keep in mind that vancomycin is less effective against staphylococci compared to beta lactams. So beta lactams are preferable over vancomycin if the pathogen is sensitive to them.

Also remember that a reasonable alternative to vancomycin is daptomycin. Dose is 6 mg/kg of body weight, IV, daily.

Now let’s look at the possible therapy if the pathogen is methicillin resistant or is coagulase negative.

Vancomycin

AHA recommends against adding rifampin to vancomycin.

Don’t combine vancomycin with gentamicin.

If the pathogen is methicillin susceptible staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) then the antimicrobial approach is the following:

One of the following beta lactam drugs can be administered.

Nafcillin in the dose of 2 g IV every four hours

Or Oxacillin  2 g IV every four hours

Or Flucloxacillin 2 g IV every six hours

title: Staphylococcus Skin Infections Impetigo Folliculitis Furuncles or Boils Carbuncles Cellulitis Surgical Wound
shortDescription: In this discussion Dr. Mobeen presents the pathophysiology, clinical aspects, and the current management approach to impetigo, foliculitis, furuncles or boils, carbuncles, cellulitis, and surgical wound infections caused by S. Aureus.
longDescription: In this discussion Dr. Mobeen presents the pathophysiology, clinical aspects, and the current management approach to impetigo, foliculitis, furuncles or boils, carbuncles, cellulitis, and surgical wound infections caused by S. Aureus.
notes:
In this discussion, Dr. Mobeen presents the pathophysiology, clinical aspects, and the current management approach to impetigo, folliculitis, furuncles or boils, carbuncles, cellulitis, and surgical wound infections caused by S. Aureus.

Introduction

We are continuing our discussion about the diseases caused by staphylococcal organ invasion. Today is the turn for the staphylococcal skin infections. We will discuss impetigo, furuncles or boils, carbuncles, and cellulitis. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome caused by exotoxin is already discussed. 

 

Most of these infections occur after a break in the skin. The infection spreads when the patient touches, scratches, or when the dressing from the wound is touched. This is why it is important to wash hands after touching the infected areas of skin and also equally important is to dispose-off the dressings carefully.

 

Folliculitis

Folliculitis is the name given to a group of skin conditions in which there are inflamed hair follicles. The result is a tender red spot, often with a surface pustule. Folliculitis may be superficial or deep and can affect any hair-bearing area of skin.

A furuncle (syn. boil) is a deeper, and more pronounced infection of the hair follicle in which purulent material extends through the dermis into the subcutaneous tissue, where a small abscess forms. A carbuncle is a coalescence of several inflamed follicles into a single inflammatory mass with purulent drainage from multiple follicles.  
http://www.pcds.org.uk/clinical-guidance/folliculitis-an-overview

Let’s summarize these infections before we dive deeper. Impetigo is the infection of the superficial layers or epidermis of the skin. Folliculitis is the infection of a single hair follicle. Furuncle or a boil is a folliculitis that is more pronounced and spills over to the neighboring tissue especially extending through the dermis to the deeper subcutaneous tissue. When many furuncles are near each other and communicate with each other, then these are called a carbuncle. And, finally, cellulitis is the non-suppurative infection of the deeper tissue mostly involving deep dermis and subcutaneous layers. Let us now discuss these conditions and their management one by one.

 

Impetigo

It is a highly contagious infection of the superficial skin layers. It occurs mostly in infants and children. Most commonly it starts under the nose as small vesicles that break and crust over. This honey-colored crust or scab is made of dried serum. Scab is removed leaving a red mark that soon resolves without any scarring. Impetigo can spread in hot and humid climates. Also, note that if there are areas of skin burns or skin breaks, then impetigo can spread into these areas causing cellulitis.

Tests and labs

A pus swab is taken for culture on blood agar or chocolate agar.

Treatment

  • Mild infections should be treated with topical mupirocin or fusidic acid.
  • Remove crusts with topical antiseptics, water, and soap.
  • The staphylococcal nasal carriage should be treated as well. Use chlorhexidine with neomycin for this purpose. Chronic, recurrent, and resistant cases may need treatment with mupirocin nasal ointment. Usually administered in the nares for ten days.

 

Let’s talk now about the localized skin infections that are furuncles/boils, carbuncles, and cellulitis.

Furuncles or Boils

Recall that folliculitis is the infection of a single hair follicle. When this infection becomes pronounced and spills out of the follicle into deeper layers, then it is called a furuncle. Usually, furuncles occur in youngsters and males. Most common locations are the neck, shoulders, and anogenital areas. Furuncles repeatedly occur in people that are Staphylococcus aureus carriers. Tight clothes causing skin friction leading to hair follicle injury and skin breaks can cause furuncles.

 

Carbuncles

Many nearby furuncles that communicate with each other are called carbuncles. Carbuncles develop dome-shaped, skin lesions that are very painful, and mostly have purulent discharge. Diabetic and immunosuppressed patients are especially at risk. Additionally, poor hygiene, malnourishment, addiction, heart failure, other skin diseases, and prolonged steroid therapy can lead to carbuncles as well.

Treatment

Both the furuncles and carbuncles can be treated with the following therapy.

  1. Flucloxacillin for S. Aureus and Penicillin for Strep pyogenes. Erythromycin or clarithromycin in case of penicillin sensitivity. One week therapy is sufficient in acute cases. Chronic cases may need two-week therapy with nasal carriage treatment.
  2. For carbuncles, surgical incision and drainage may be needed.

 

Cellulitis

Cellulitis is a non-suppurative deeper tissue infection. Non-suppurative means there is no discharge. Overlying skin looks hot, red, shiny, and swollen. An important clinical point to note is that any suspicion of mid-facial cellulitis should be immediately treated otherwise cavernous sinus thrombosis can occur. Cellulitis can be caused by S. Aureus, Streptococci or Clostridium perfringens. You might see systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) symptoms. For example, tachycardia, tachypnea, increased or reduced temperature, leukocytosis, or leukopenia. Also fever, chills, rigors may also be present. A bacterial sample for culture is usually difficult to obtain, a punch biopsy of the tissue may be useful. Make sure to rule out bone infections and necrotizing fasciitis before diagnosing cellulitis.

 

Surgical Wound Infections

Finally, let’s quickly discuss the last type of skin infection by S. Aureus. This is the surgical wound infection by S. Aureus. In such cases, you may have to cut the sutures and leave the wound open to heal by second intention.

 

Complications

  • Furuncles and carbuncles can leave scars.
  • They can lead to cellulitis as well.
  • Rarely cavernous sinus thrombosis, osteomyelitis, brain abscesses, acute endocarditis, and/or renal carbuncle can occur.

 

General principles of treatment

  • Nasal carriage for ten days.
  • One week with antibiotics
  • Two weeks with antibiotics in chronic cases

title: Streptococcus Pyogenes - Clinical Foundations
shortDescription: Did you know that streptococcus pyogenes is the most virulent of all streptococcal species? We are sure that strep/sore throat is a routine presentation in your clinic. In the US only streptococci pyogenes cause millions of yearly visits to healthcare facilities. Streptococci cause disease by direct organ invasion, by their enzymes, and by releasing exotoxins. Understanding streptococci thoroughly and then wielding a great command over the management approach will help you continue to be amazing for your patients. In this two part series we will talk about the streptococcal foundations necessary to understand and manage the disease, and then various diseases and their management. Let's start with the first part here. Make sure that you have understood this before the second part about the diseases and their management.
longDescription:
We are sure that strep/sore throat is a routine presentation in your clinic. In the US only streptococci pyogenes cause millions of yearly visits to healthcare facilities. Streptococci cause disease by direct organ invasion, by their enzymes, and by releasing exotoxins. Understanding streptococci thoroughly and then wielding a great command over the management approach will help you continue to be amazing for your patients. In this two-part series, we will talk about the streptococcal foundations necessary to understand and manage the disease, and then various diseases and their management. Let's start with the first part here. Make sure that you have understood this before the second part about the diseases and their management.

In this lecture we will discuss the following topics:

  • Virulence potential
  • Habitat
    • Throat
    • Skin
  • Tests
    • Erythrogenic/Pyogenic exotoxin
    • Gram +
    • PYR +
    • RAD
    • Catalase -
    • Bacitracin sensitive
  • Antigenic components of the cell wall
    • Hyaluronic acid
    • C carbs
    • M Proteins
    • Exotoxins
  • Enzymes
    • Streptolysin O
    • Streptolysin S
    • Streptokinase
    • Hyaluronidase
    • DNAse
    • C5a Peptidase


These foundations will be used to look at the disease process, disease types, and the disease management in the next lecture.
notes:
Introduction

In this lecture, we will discuss the clinically important points related to streptococcus pyogenes.

Streptococcus pyogenes is the most virulent pathogen of all streptococci.

  • It is a beta-hemolytic pathogen. That is, it causes complete lysis of red blood cells.
  • It also is bacitracin sensitive. Remember the other pathogen in this group, that is, streptococcus agalactiae are bacitracin resistant.
  • And, finally, Streptococcus pyogenes is PYR +

By the way, the word pyogenes means pus-producing. You will see that this pathogen causes tissue liquefaction resulting in pus formation. A little later in this lecture, you will read the enzymes that help break down tissues to allow this pathogen to spread.

Habitat

Streptococcus pyogenes is the normal flora of our throat and skin.

Structure

Hyaluronic Acid Capsule

This capsule is antiphagocytic. Hyaluronic acid in the capsule binds to CD44 or hyaluronic acid binding protein on our epithelium. This binding leads to the disruption of intracellular junctions, breaking the cell to cell adhesion. This mechanism separates the cells creating a path for the pathogen to penetrate deeper in the tissue without becoming intracellular.

Cell Wall

C Carbohydrates

C carbohydrates were used by Rebecca Lancefield for Streptococcal classification. The C carbohydrate on strep pyogenes is of type A. This is why we label streptococcus pyogenes as group A pathogen.

M Proteins

Another important component of the cell wall is the M protein. This protein is antigenic. In the capsular strains of the streptococci, it protrudes from the capsule forming little pili. These pili are also covered by lipoteichoic acid. M protein is important because it inactivates the alternate complement pathway activation, preventing phagocytosis.

M proteins, however, is also the weakest part of the pathogen. Our B cells make anti-M protein antibodies that opsonize the pathogen by attaching to the M proteins. Once opsonized, the pathogen can now be easily cleared away by the phagocytes and neutrophils that bind to the Fc part of the antibodies and pick up this pathogen and destroy it.

I find it funny that on one end the M protein destroys complement to prevent phagocytosis, but then our immune system coats them with the antibodies, making them yummy for our phagocytic cells, that phagocytose the pathogen. Immune system 1, streptococci 0. Take-that streptococci!

Enzymes

Note: Streptococci have many enzymes that are similar to staphylococci in their function. Hence, many infections are similar too. And, this is why usually for the skin infections you will give treatment that covers both streptococci and staphylococci.

Important enzymes are, Streptolysin O, Streptolysin S, Streptokinase, Hyaluronidase, DNAse A, B, C, and D; and C5a peptidase

Streptolysin O 

Remember O in streptolysin O stands for oxygen labile. This enzyme is a hemolysin. That is it destroys blood by destroying red and white blood cells. This enzyme is also antigenic. We produce antibodies against it which can be measured to identify recent infection. This antibody is called anti-streptolysin-O or ASO. You will routinely order ASO titers in the wards. Usually, 160 to 200 units are significant.

Streptolysin S 

S in streptolysin S stands for oxygen stabile. This enzyme is also hemolysin and takes part in breaking RBCs and WBCs. However, remember, it is not antigenic.

Streptokinase 

Streptokinase helps activate plasmin from plasminogen. Plasmin, in turn, breaks fibrin in the clots. This, in turn, helps the pathogen escape clots. Due to this property streptokinase is also used in the hospital wards during MIs.

Hyaluronidase 

It splits hyaluronic acid. Hyaluronic acid is an important part of the ground substance of the connective tissue. This enzyme helps streptococci break the tissue to invade and spread. This tissue liquefaction also results in pus formation.

DNAses

There are four types of DNAses that streptococci produce, DNAse A,B,C, and D. As the name suggests, these enzymes also help break down the tissue to allow the bacteria to spread. Anti DNAse B antibodies are produced by our immune system. These antibodies can be measured to confirm a recent streptococcal infection.

C5a Peptidase 

This enzyme breaks the C5a protein resulting in chemotaxis prevention. This in turn delays the immune response and allows the pathogen to establish.

 

Exotoxins, diseases, and their management in the next lecture.

title: Eating Disorders
longDescription:
In this lecture, we will talk about the presentation, diagnosis and treatment approaches to a range of eating disorders.

 

An eating disorder is when a patient has an unhealthy attitude to food, which can take over your life and make you ill. It can involve eating too much or too little or becoming obsessed with their weight and body shape. Men and women of any age can get an eating disorder, but they most commonly affect young women aged 13 to 17 years old. 
In this lecture we will talk about the three most common eating disorders:

  • Anorexia nervosa 
  • Bulimia
  • Binge eating disorder (BED)
notes:

title: Personality Disorders
shortDescription:
In this lectur we will talk about the presentation to a range of personality disorders. 

A person with a personality disorder will
think differently, 
Feel differently
behave differently 
or relates to others very differently from the average person.

The DSM-V states there are several different types of personality disorder, split into 3 clusters: 
Continue ...
longDescription:
In this lecture, we will talk about the presentation to a range of personality disorders. 

A person with a personality disorder will
think differently, 
Feel differently
behave differently 
or relates to others very differently from the average person.

The DSM-V states there are several different types of personality disorder, split into 3 clusters: 
Cluster A: Peculiar thought processes, inappropriate affect – remember them as WEIRD
Cluster B: Mood lability, dissociative symptoms, preoccupation with rejection remember them as WILD
Cluster C: Anxiety, preoccupation with criticism or rigidity remember them as WORRIED

Causes
It's not clear exactly what causes personality disorders, but they're thought to result from a combination of the genes a person inherits and early environmental influences – for example, a distressing childhood experience (such as abuse or neglect).

Prevalence:
All are relatively common.
More males have antisocial and narcissistic PDs
More females have borderline and histrionic PDs. 

Onset:
Usually not diagnosed until late adolescence or early adulthood 

Course. 
Usually very chronic over decades without treatment. 
Symptoms of paranoid, schizoid, and narcissistic PD often worsen with age; 
symptoms of antisocial and borderline PD often ameliorate. 

Key Symptoms. 
A long pattern of difficult interpersonal relationships, problems adapting to stress, failure to achieve goals, chronic unhappiness, low self-esteem 

Personality disorders are usually associated with mood disorders.

Treatment: 
Psychotherapy is the mainstay of treatment. Intensive and long-term psychodynamic and cognitive therapy are treatments of choice for most PDs. 
Use of mood stabilizers and antidepressants is sometimes useful for Cluster B PDs. 

Differential Diagnosis: 
Major rule-outs are mood disorders, personality change due to a general medical condition, and adjustment disorders.

title: Psychotic Disorders
shortDescription:
In this lecture Dr. Adam Jones discusses the pathophysiology, presentation, diagnosis, and treatment approaches for a range of psychotic disorders. 
Discussion especially includes the following disorders:
Delusions
Hallucinations
Schizophrenia
longDescription: In this lecture, Dr Jones will discuss the clinically important points related to psychotic disorders. Psychotic disorders are severe mental disorders that cause abnormal thinking and perceptions. People with psychoses lose touch with reality. Two of the main symptoms are delusions and hallucinations. Delusions are false beliefs, such as thinking that someone is plotting against you or that the TV is sending you secret messages. Hallucinations are false perceptions, such as hearing, seeing, or feeling something that is not there. Schizophrenia is one type of psychotic disorder. Psychosis can also be caused by alcohol, some drugs, brain tumours, brain infections, stroke and mood disorders such as bipolar. This lecture will discuss Schizophrenia, Brief Psychotic disorder and Schizophreniform disorders.
notes:
In this lecture Dr. Adam Jones discusses the pathophysiology, presentation, diagnosis, and treatment approaches for a range of psychotic disorders. 
Discussion especially includes the following disorders:

  • Delusions
  • Hallucinations
  • Schizophrenia

title: Streptococcus Pyogenes - Diseases and The Management Approach
shortDescription:
What 3 categories of diseases are caused by streptococcus pyogenes?
What are the CDC's recommendations for managing strep throat? 
How does the flesh eating disease pathogen (streptococcus pyogenes) cause the tissue to die?
Why most of the post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis patients may not need hospitalization?
What is the role of clindamycin while managing streptococcal diseases?
longDescription:
What 3 categories of diseases are caused by streptococcus pyogenes?
What are the CDC's recommendations for managing strep throat? 
How does the flesh eating disease pathogen (streptococcus pyogenes) cause the tissue to die?
Why most of the post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis patients may not need hospitalization?
What is the role of clindamycin while managing streptococcal diseases?

 

Dr. Mobeen dicusses the following diseases in this lecture:

  • Pyogenic (tissue invasion)
    • Sore Throat
    • Skin Infections
      • Folliculitis
      • Pyoderma/Pustules
      • Cellulitis
      • Erysipelas
      • Impetigo
  • Toxigenic (exotoxin mediated)
    • Scarlet Fever
    • Toxic Shock Like Syndrome
    • Necrotizing Fasciitis
  • Immunogenic (immune response mediated)
    • Rheumatic Fever
    • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

Notes to be posted soon.
notes:
What 3 categories of diseases are caused by streptococcus pyogenes?
What are the CDC's recommendations for managing strep throat? 
How does the flesh eating disease pathogen (streptococcus pyogenes) cause the tissue to die?
Why most of the post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis patients may not need hospitalization?
What is the role of clindamycin while managing streptococcal diseases?

 

Dr. Mobeen dicusses the following diseases in this lecture:

  • Pyogenic (tissue invasion)
    • Sore Throat
    • Skin Infections
      • Folliculitis
      • Pyoderma/Pustules
      • Cellulitis
      • Erysipelas
      • Impetigo
  • Toxigenic (exotoxin mediated)
    • Scarlet Fever
    • Toxic Shock Like Syndrome
    • Necrotizing Fasciitis
  • Immunogenic (immune response mediated)
    • Rheumatic Fever
    • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

Streptococcal Pharyngitis 

This is also called strep throat or a streptococcal sore throat. You will see patients with strep throat frequently. In the US alone, strep throat causes seven million medical visits yearly. It usually spreads from person to person by saliva or nasal secretions.

Tissue Binding

Streptococcus pyogenes adheres to the fibronectin on pharyngeal epithelium by the lipoteichoic acid covering the pili. Another way that the streptococcus pyogenes binds to our epithelium is by the hyaluronic acid capsule binding with CD44 of our epithelial cells.

Presentation

In small children, there is thin serous discharge, little fever, and possibly infection spreading to the middle ear and mastoid. Cervical lymph nodes are usually enlarged. This disease is more intense in older children and adults, characterized by intense tonsillitis, nasopharyngitis, and edema with purulent exudate.

Treatment

CDC recommends Penicillin in non-allergic patients.

  • Penicillin V children 250 mg twice or thrice daily, adults 250 mg four times daily or 500 mg twice daily. For 10 days.
  • Or Amoxicillin 50 mg/kg once daily (max 1000 mg) for 10 days.
  • Benzathine Penicillin G IM. 1 dose. < 27 kg 60,000 Units, > 27 kg 120,000 units.

 

For individuals with penicillin allergy

  • Cephalexin,a oral    20 mg/kg/dose twice daily (max = 500 mg/dose)    10 days
  • Cefadroxil,a oral    30 mg/kg once daily (max = 1 g)    10 days
  • Clindamycin, oral    7 mg/kg/dose 3 times daily (max = 300 mg/dose)    10 days
  • Azithromycin,b oral    12 mg/kg once daily (max = 500 mg)    5 days
  • Clarithromycinb, oral    7.5 mg/kg/dose twice daily (max = 250 mg/dose)    10 days

 

Streptococcal skin infections

Skin infections by the streptococcus pyogenes range from the infection of a hair follicle called folliculitis to deep tissue infections called cellulitis.

Most of the skin infections caused by streptococci can also be caused by staphylococci. Hence, the treatment should have antibiotics that cover both pathogens, for example, penicillinase-resistant penicillins like dicloxacillin.

Streptococcus pyogenes cellulitis

Streptococci cellulitis is the infection of deeper skin layers. Usually, the overlying tissue appears, red, hot, and mildly swollen. However, note this carefully, that it is not easy to determine the boundary between the healthy and the infected tissue.

Erysipelas

Streptococci also cause erysipelas which is rarely caused by staphylococci. Erysipelas is the infection of superficial skin layers. It is characterized by an area of swollen skin with a clear boundary. This infection is routinely seen on a patient’s face and can involve the ears as well. Remember that ears are made of superficial skin layers. This is why erysipelas can infect them because erysipelas infects superficial skin layers.

Pyoderma/Pustules

This is the skin infection often seen on the extremities and the face. It breaks down in a few days leaving a crust that heals slowly. There is an area of depigmentation at the location of the pustule.

Exotoxin Mediated Diseases

Three diseases in this class are important, scarlet fever, toxic shock-like syndrome, and necrotizing fasciitis.

Scarlet Fever

Scarlet fever is mediated by the pyrogenic or erythrogenic exotoxin. Patient has a scarlet red rash that begins on the trunk and neck and then spreads to the extremities. This erythematous rash  blanches on pressure. This rash also has a sandpaper quality and is accentuated in the flexor creases. Palms, soles, and face are usually spare. Face is flushed and looks red, but this is not the rash. There is also a characteristic pallor around the mouth called circumoral pallor.

Remember that the exotoxin is acquired by the lysogenic conversion. Lysogenic conversion is where a gene from one bacteria gets incorporated into a phage that carries this gene into another bacteria providing this next bacteria with the new capability by this incoming gene. In case of Streptococcus pyogenes, a phage can bring the gene for the pyrogenic or erythrogenic exotoxin.

Treatment for the pathogen is the same as described for pharyngitis above.

Toxic Shock Syndrome

Pain is the most common presentation. Usually involves an extremity but may mimic peritonitis, myocardial infarction, pneumonia, pericarditis, etc. Some patients may even have influenza-like symptoms of fever, chills, nausea, diarrhea, myalgia, etc.There may be signs of tissue infection.

On admission to hospital patients are usually in shock and renal dysfunction.

Given the complexity of a toxic shock, presenting a good treatment approach here is impossible. Having said that, Penicillin and Clindamycin are the drugs that can be used in addition to other medications to support the toxic shock patient. Some researchers have shown that clindamycin is more potent in TSS than penicillin due to its strong suppression of the bacterial toxin synthesis.

https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/1/3/95-0301_article

Necrotizing Fasciitis

Streptococcus strain that can cause necrotizing fasciitis is also called flesh-eating streptococcus. Bacteria enter through a skin breach which may have occurred due to trauma, burn, or surgery. M protein helps prevent phagocytosis while the hyaluronic acid capsule binds with the CD44 of the cells disrupting the intracellular adhesions. This leads to the ability of the pathogen to penetrate deep and infect the fascia. You may be wondering why this disease is toxin-mediated? The reason is that it is the toxin that starts the process of apoptosis in the cells leading to necrosis. 

Within 24 hours the patient develops swelling, heat, and redness of the area infected. Another day later the skin color changes from red to purple to blue. Large bullae form. Finally, the skin dies and myositis may occur as well.

Treatment

This infection should be rapidly recognized and fascia surgically removed. Additionally, penicillin and clindamycin are given in high doses. Remember clindamycin blocks streptococcal metabolism reducing the toxin and enzyme production. Even with the surgery and antibiotics, the mortality rate is greater than fifty percent > 50%.

Immunologic diseases.

Rheumatic Fever

With the advent of antibiotics, rheumatic fever is less common nowadays.

This disease occurs after streptococcal pharyngitis, however, it does not occur after streptococcal skin infections. Keep in mind that the second immunogenic disease is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis which can occur after streptococcal pharyngitis or skin infections.

As we already know that streptococcal M proteins are antigenic. Our immune system develops anti M proteins antibodies. Unfortunately, our heart tissue also have proteins that look like M proteins. This results in the newly formed antibodies to attack or cross-react with the cardiac tissue resulting in the cardiac valve and heart muscle damage.

Usually, the mitral valve is damaged first. To remember this, note the M protein and M for the mitral valve. The aortic valve is damaged next.

The immune cross-reaction occurs within 1 to 5 weeks of the original infection. Mean duration is 19 days after the infection.

Patient presents with fever, malaise, joint pains, and the evidence of damage to the heart valves, muscles, or even pericardium. Following mnemonic should help you remember the presenting complaints.

JONES Mnemonic

J for Joints. Patient complaints of migratory joint pains. Luckily there is no long-term joint damage.

O for the heart. Evidence of cardiac valve, and muscle damage.

N for nodules. There are subcutaneous, painless, rubbery nodules.

E for erythema marginatum. A red rash with a margin. It spreads out from its center.

S for Sydenham's chorea or involuntary movements due to neurologic issues.

In the patients of RF, prophylactic penicillin is required for life of the patient to prevent future beta-hemolytic streptococcal infections and further cardiac damage.

Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis

Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis can occur about a week after the streptococcal throat or skin infection. This disease is also immunogenic. Streptococcal antigens and antibody complexes are formed. These complexes tumble around and finally deposit in the glomeruli resulting in the immune reaction at the glomeruli and renal damage.

The patient usually presents with a puffy face and tea or coca-cola colored urine. On examination, you will find the patient is hypertensive due to hypervolemia from water retention.

This disease has a good prognosis and a majority of the patients recover completely.

By the time patient presents to you the damage to the kidney is done. Treatment is usually supportive. However, if you decide to admit the patient then the discharge is indicated when diuresis starts and the blood pressure returns to normal.

title: Cerebrospinal Fluid
shortDescription:
Cerebrospinal fluid is colorless fluid that fills the nervous system cavities. It acts as a protective cushion, and also is the vehicle for nutrient's exchange. 
Understanding the production, flow, drainage, and composition of the CSF is critical for a medical professional.
longDescription:
Cerebrospinal fluid is a colorless fluid that fills the nervous system cavities. It acts as a protective cushion, and also is the vehicle for nutrient's exchange. 
Understanding the production, flow, drainage, and composition of the CSF is critical for a medical professional.

In this talk Dr. Mobeen presents the following topics:

  • 1. The structures taking part in the formation of the blood-brain barrier
  • 2. Production of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
  • 3. Circulation of CSF
  • 5. The composition of CSF in the following events:
    • Bacterial meningitis
    • Viral meningitis
    • Fungal meningitis
    • Tuberculosis
    • Trauma

title: Catatonia
shortDescription: In this lecture, we will discuss the clinically relevant points of Catatonia. Catatonia is an abnormal neuropsychiatric condition that affects both behavior and motor function, and results in unresponsiveness in someone who otherwise appears to be awake.
longDescription:
In this lecture, we will discuss the clinically relevant points of Catatonia. Catatonia is an abnormal neuropsychiatric condition that affects both behavior and motor function, and results in unresponsiveness in someone who otherwise appears to be awake.

For the purpose of diagnosis, there are three types of catatonia, including catatonia associated with another mental disorder, catatonia disorder due to another medical condition, and unspecified catatonia.

Although often associated with schizophrenia and other affective disorders, catatonia may be a result of, or due to, any number of psychotic disorders, mood disorders or general medical conditions. Catatonia is sometimes referred to as catatonic syndrome, because there is not just one identifying sign or symptom associated with this condition or symptoms that appear separately from one another, but rather a collection of several symptoms that appear together at the same time.

These specific signs and symptoms do not vary, regardless of the nature of the condition. In terms of symptoms…

Catatonia can be stuporous or excited. Stuporous catatonia is characterised by immobility during which people may hold rigid poses (stupor), an inability to speak (mutism), as well as waxy flexibility, in which they maintain positions after being placed in them by someone else. Mutism may be partial and they may repeat meaningless phrases or speak only to repeat what someone else says. People with stuporous catatonia may also show stereotyped, repetitive movements (stereotypy).

Excited catatonia is characterised by bizarre, non-goal directed hyperactivity and impulsiveness.

 

How do you diagnose this condition? Well, according to DSM-5, at least three out of twelve symptoms must be present for a diagnosis of catatonia. These symptoms include:

 

 

• Stupor (oblivious inability to move or respond to stimuli), catalepsy (rigid body posture)

• Mutism (little to no verbal communication) • Waxy flexibility (body remains in whatever position it is placed by another)

• Negativism (lack of verbal response) • Posturing (holding a posture or position that goes against gravity)

• Mannerisms (extreme or odd movements and mannerisms)

• Stereotypy (frequent repetitive movements for no reason)

• Agitation (for no reason), grimacing (distorted facial expressions)

• Echolalia (repeating others’ words)

• Echopraxia (repeating others’ movements).

 

When catatonia is associated with schizophrenia, stupor may continue for long periods of time as compared to schizophrenia associated with other psychiatric conditions, where there are likely to be long remissions.

 

So what causes Catatonia? Well, Catatonia is generally associated with, or due to, other medical conditions, especially brain disorders such as neurodegenerative disease and encephalitis. A severe vitamin B12 deficiency; infection; exposure to toxins; or conditions such as schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders, autism, extreme trauma, and mood disorders are also associated with catatonia. Catatonia can also be idiopathic, arising from an unknown cause. Any general medical patient who displays obvious related symptoms may be catatonic. The link between catatonia due to or associated with general medical conditions is unclear and the condition often goes unrecognized, but when identified, responds to standard catatonia treatments.
notes:
In this lecture, we will discuss the clinically relevant points of Catatonia. Catatonia is an abnormal neuropsychiatric condition that affects both behavior and motor function, and results in unresponsiveness in someone who otherwise appears to be awake.

For the purpose of diagnosis, there are three types of catatonia, including catatonia associated with another mental disorder, catatonia disorder due to another medical condition, and unspecified catatonia.

Although often associated with schizophrenia and other affective disorders, catatonia may be a result of, or due to, any number of psychotic disorders, mood disorders or general medical conditions. Catatonia is sometimes referred to as catatonic syndrome, because there is not just one identifying sign or symptom associated with this condition or symptoms that appear separately from one another, but rather a collection of several symptoms that appear together at the same time.

These specific signs and symptoms do not vary, regardless of the nature of the condition. In terms of symptoms…

Catatonia can be stuporous or excited. Stuporous catatonia is characterised by immobility during which people may hold rigid poses (stupor), an inability to speak (mutism), as well as waxy flexibility, in which they maintain positions after being placed in them by someone else. Mutism may be partial and they may repeat meaningless phrases or speak only to repeat what someone else says. People with stuporous catatonia may also show stereotyped, repetitive movements (stereotypy).

Excited catatonia is characterised by bizarre, non-goal directed hyperactivity and impulsiveness.

 

How do you diagnose this condition? Well, according to DSM-5, at least three out of twelve symptoms must be present for a diagnosis of catatonia. These symptoms include:

 

 

• Stupor (oblivious inability to move or respond to stimuli), catalepsy (rigid body posture)

• Mutism (little to no verbal communication) • Waxy flexibility (body remains in whatever position it is placed by another)

• Negativism (lack of verbal response) • Posturing (holding a posture or position that goes against gravity)

• Mannerisms (extreme or odd movements and mannerisms)

• Stereotypy (frequent repetitive movements for no reason)

• Agitation (for no reason), grimacing (distorted facial expressions)

• Echolalia (repeating others’ words)

• Echopraxia (repeating others’ movements).

 

When catatonia is associated with schizophrenia, stupor may continue for long periods of time as compared to schizophrenia associated with other psychiatric conditions, where there are likely to be long remissions.

 

So what causes Catatonia? Well, Catatonia is generally associated with, or due to, other medical conditions, especially brain disorders such as neurodegenerative disease and encephalitis. A severe vitamin B12 deficiency; infection; exposure to toxins; or conditions such as schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders, autism, extreme trauma, and mood disorders are also associated with catatonia. Catatonia can also be idiopathic, arising from an unknown cause. Any general medical patient who displays obvious related symptoms may be catatonic. The link between catatonia due to or associated with general medical conditions is unclear and the condition often goes unrecognized, but when identified, responds to standard catatonia treatments.
